Continuing Efforts to Improve Safety
  
As part of Hillshire Brands' continuous efforts to improve the safety of the system, we continue to implement system updates and modification - including equipment / piping replacements and relocations to safer locations.  We also continue to revise / update operating procedures as needed and perform regular ammonia safety training.

Also, to ensure the mechanical integrity of critical refrigeration system components, regular 109 inspections are conducted. We also do NDT Testing every 5 years to insure our piping and vessel integrity.

 In accordance with the PSM program, Tyson conducts detailed PSM compliance audits at least every three years that incorporate review of process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training programs, system mechanical integrity, management of change, pre-start up review procedures, compliance audit procedures, incident investigation procedures, employee participation programs, hot work permit procedures, and contractor safety procedures.

Hillshire Brands' insurance carrier also conducts independent audits on a regular basis.

Five-Year Accident History

Over the last five years, Hillshire Brands has not experienced an accidental off-site release of anhydrous ammonia from the ammonia refrigeration system.

Emergency Response Program

Hillshire Brands has documented emergency response procedures in the Facility's Emergency Response / Evacuation Plan in order to facilitate response efforts in the event of an on-site anhydrous ammonia release.  Included in the SOP are measures to be taken internally by Hillshire Brands as well as measures to be taken by off-site response agencies.

Hillshire Brands has trained approximately 55 on-site personnel to respond to accidental ammonia releases.  These personnel receive training and take part in monthly Hazmat meetings.  As an additional training exercise, Hillshire Brands periodically holds simulations of an emergency release with off-site effects.  The simulations are conducted with the entire emergency response system and involves coordination between Hillshire Brands' Hazmat team and offsite loc

Accidental Release Prevention Program

To prevent and mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, Hillshire Brands has implemented certain precautionary measures, including process / equipment controls, procedures, preventative maintenance programs, employee training and auditing.  In addition, Hillshire Brands' ammonia refrigeration system is designed and constructed in accordance with accepted industry standards and good engineering practices.

Hillshire Brands has also developed and implemented a PSM program pursuant to OSHA regulations and as such, has evaluated the system for the potential of anhydrous ammonia releases.   Some of the controls installed to prevent catastrophic releases of ammonia are process equipment (vents, pressure relief valves, backup pumps, and manual shutoffs) and automated controls (automatic shut-offs, ammonia leak detection system, and electrical distribution system grounding).  In addition, Hillshire Brands has trained approximately 55 team members to respond to potential ammonia releases (HazMat team).

Hillshire Brands has developed standard operating procedures for all equipment in the ammonia refrigeration system that incorporate safety measures into the procedures.  These safety procedures were developed by refrigeration system operators and are recertified annually. Hillshire Brands encourages employee participation in development of the control measures used at the plant by means of meetings and training sessions. Changes to the operating procedures are to be communicated to affected employees.
Hillshire Brands understands that maintaining the refrigeration system in good working order is essential to preventing accidental releases; therefore Hillshire Brands has implemented a preventative maintenance program.  Th

The worst-case release scenario was developed following EPA regulations and is not considered by Hillshire Brands to be a likely release scenario for the facility. During normal operations, Hillshire Brands maintains the receivers at no more than 60% capacity. Only during pump-down operations do the receivers have the potential to be filled to 80% of capacity. The receivers are operated in pump-down mode less than 1% of the time during the year.

Alternative Release Scenario

Tyson Foods has chosen the alternative release scenario of a pressure relief valve activation.  Pressure relief valve activations historically have been the primary release type within the company based on reports to Environmental Compliance.  The Zeeland, MI facility has one Pressure relief valve that meets this air rating.  The Parker RS-SRH3 SRV is located on the 30 Deg Accumulator.  The valve has an inlet port size of 3/4 and an outlet port size of 1-1/4 and discharge flow rating of 2068 pounds per minute (air rating) at a pressure setting of 250 psig. Background Data

In accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 68 (40 CFR 68) promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Hillshire Brands - Zeeland submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at their Zeeland, Michigan facility. Main operations at the Hillshire Brands - Zeeland Facility include processing/packaging of turkey, chicken, beef, and pork products. In addition to processing meats, the Hillshire Brands - Zeeland Facility operates an automated breakfast bowls assembly and packaging line. Hillshire Brands has been in operation at this location since 1936 providing quality meat products and over 1122 jobs to the local community.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

Hillshire Brands is committed to protecting the health of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment. It is Hillshire Brands' policy to maintain a safe and healthy workplace, protect the environment, and comply with all applicable regulations, including 40 CFR 68 and, as applicable, Occupational Safety and Health Organization (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations promulgated as Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Chapter 1910, Section 119 (29 CFR 1910.119), and OSHA's Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations (29 CFR 1910.120).

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

Hillshire Brands is required to maintain low temperatures in the food processing areas of the plant that are within standards required by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) to ensure quality in the final products. Hillshire Brands also operates freezers and coolers for product storage. Hillshire Brands uses anhydrous ammonia (the 112(r) regulated substance) as a refrigerant to maintain the 592,451.34 sq.ft. facility within the required range of operating temperatures and to operate the freezers and coolers.
